#Text=Tranquility Bass

#Text=Tranquility Bass was the stage name of Michael Adam Kandel , [ 2 ] ( 1967/1968 – May 17 , 2015 ) an American musician whose music has been variously categorized as ambient house , trip hop , and funk rock .
#Text=He released various singles during the 1990s , followed by his first full-length album , Let The Freak Flag Fly , in 1997 on Astralwerks .
#Text=Early life
#Text=Kandel was born and raised in Chicago .
#Text=He learned to play guitar and keyboards at age 12 .
#Text=By the age of 15 he had begun to record experimental electronic music in his bedroom . [ 3 ]
#Text=Musical career
#Text=Kandel attended the Chicago Academy for the Arts , after which he moved to Los Angeles in the early 1990s to attend CalArts .
#Text=It was there that he met Tom Chasteen , with whom he started the Exist Dance label in 1991 . [ 4 ]
#Text=The two released several singles , including some as Tranquility Bass , later that year . [ 3 ]

#Text=In 1993 , Kandel released the single " They Came in Peace " , which has been described as an ambient-house classic and appeared on the Mo ' Wax compilation album Headz the following year . [ 4 ]
#Text=After the duo released this and a few other singles , including two songs that appeared on the FFRR compilation album , California Dreaming in 1994 , [ 5 ]
#Text=Chasteen left Tranquility Bass and relocated to Tucson . [ 6 ]
#Text=Tranquility Bass 's touring bassist , Matt Lux , is also the bassist for Chicago-based band Isotope 217 . [ 7 ]
#Text=Let the Freak Flag Fly
#Text=In 1994 , after Chasteen 's departure , Kandel joined Tyler Vlaovich to record an album on Lopez Island in Washington . [ 8 ]
#Text=More than two years later , the album was released as Let the Freak Flag Fly on Astralwerks Records . [ 6 ]
#Text=Kandel sometimes ceased talking to people , or from using his voice , for two or three days on end during the recording process . [ 8 ]
#Text=According to Billboard , the album led to Kandel developing " a cult following that spans several genres beyond the dance realm . " [ 9 ]

column1: #Text=The Los Angeles Times gave the album a rating of three stars ( out of four ) and described it as " the electronic progeny of acid rock . " [ 10 ]

#Text=It was also reviewed favorably by Greg Kot , who described it as " a grand journey through nearly a century of recorded music , a densely layered montage of electronic manipulations and live instruments made under conditions that were certainly unusual . " [ 11 ]
#Text=The album contained the song " We All Want To Be Free " , made more popular by its airplay on MTV 's Amp . [ 12 ]
#Text=Heartbreaks & Hallelujahs
#Text=After a long hiatus from studio recording and rumors of drug abuse , Kandel returned in 2012 with a sophomore effort entitled Heartbreaks & Hallelujahs .
#Text=The album was completed on March 21 , 2002 .
#Text=Kandel reportedly tried to have the album released on multiple labels , only to have each of them fold after he sent it to them . [ 13 ]
#Text=The album ended up being released on Exist Dance , although it is readily available in digital format on Amazon MP3 and iTunes .
#Text=The album is mostly new material with the exception of yet another remix of an early days single , " Mike 's House " . [ 14 ]

#Text=Kandel seemed to try to get away from the idea of being an electronic musician ( although some of the album still has electronics ) , with a dose of various types of rock such as funk rock and surf rock .
#Text=Death
#Text=Tranquility Bass died on May 17 , 2015 , aged 47 in Chicago suburb Buffalo Grove , IL . [ 15 ]
#Text=A cause of death was not released to the public .
